Fig. 1 Catalytic performance of NiMgOx in DRM reaction as a function of reaction temperature: (A) MS signals for the conversion of CH4 and CO2 as well as the formation of H2 and CO during TPSR test; (B) conversion of CH4 and CO2; (C) H2/CO ratio; (D) ratios for CO2/CH4 conversion and H2/CO formation at 500, 550 and 650 °C. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Long-term stability of NiMgOx catalyst in the DRM reactions at 500, 550 and 650 °C: (A) CH4 conversion; (B) CO2 conversion; (C) H2/CO ratio (Dotted lines indicate thermodynamic equilibrium values, and the slight deviation from the equilibrium will be discussed in the following sections). Fig 2 Fig. 3 Catalyst structure: (A) XRD patterns of NiMgOx catalysts (a, as-prepared catalyst; b–d, spent catalyst after DRM reaction at 500 °C for 48 h, 550 °C for 9 h and 650 °C for 78 h) (Symbol ♦, carbon; •, MgNiO2; ▾, Ni); (B–F) EDX element mapping and TEM images of the spent catalyst at 650 °C for 78 h. Fig 3 Fig. 4 (A) XPS Ni 2p spectra and (B) Raman spectra of the spent NiMgOx catalysts after DRM reactions at different temperatures. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Thermodynamic characteristics of the key reaction steps of DRM: (A) ▵ H and (B) ▵ G as a function of reaction temperature. Fig 5 Fig. 6 (A) Normalized MS signal of H2 production and (B) comparative result in CO2-free CH4 decomposition reactions over NiMgOx catalyst at 500, 550 and 650 °C. Fig 6 Fig. 7 (A–C) TGA curves and (D–F) Raman spectra of the spent NiMgOx catalysts after CH4 decomposition reactions at different temperatures of 500, 550 and 650 °C. Fig 7 Fig. 8 (A) Normalized MS signal of CO2 production and (B) comparative result in CO disproportionation reactions over NiMgOx catalyst at 500, 550 and 650 °C. Fig 8 Fig. 9 (A–C) TGA curves and (D–F) Raman spectra of the spent NiMgOx catalysts after CO disproportionation reactions at different temperatures of 500, 550 and 650 °C. Fig 9 Fig. 10 In-situ DRIFT spectra of CO2 dissociative adsorption on NiMgOx catalyst in temperature range from 300 to 650 °C (labeling of species: a, hydroxyl; b, gaseous CO2; c, gaseous CO; d, carboxylate; e, bicarbonate; f, monodentate formate; g, bidentate carbonate; h, monodentate carbonate). Fig 10 Fig. 11 In-situ DRIFT spectra of steady-state DRM reaction over NiMgOx catalyst at temperature of (A) 500 °C; (B) 550 °C; (C) 650 °C (labeling of species: a, carboxylate; b, bridging carbonate; c, bicarbonate; d, monodentate formate; e, bidentate formate; f, bidentate carbonate; g, monodentate carbonate; h, CH4). Fig 11 Table 1 Ni/Mg ratio and size distribution of Ni0 nanoparticles in three spent NiMgOx catalysts. With pre-reduced NiMgOx catalyst, the structure evolution, catalytic performance, surface species and coking-related reaction steps are investigated in methane dry reforming (DRM) at selected temperatures. Satisfactory conversion of CH4 and CO2, H2/CO ratio, and anti-coke stability are achieved in long-term (78 h) reaction at 650 °C as a proper temperature. The characterizations evidence co-existence of metallic Ni0 and solid solution phases in the working catalysts. Combined catalytic evaluation and coke analysis reveal that, at 650 °C, endothermic CO2-free CH4 decomposition shows a high initial rate for H2 production but severe coke deposition for rapid deactivation, serving as the primary coking process. In contrast, exothermic CO disproportionation exhibits a lower reaction rate and a higher coke graphitization degree. The in-situ DRIFT spectra demonstrate that carbonates and bicarbonates serve as the primary adsorbates during CO2 dissociation process, whereas formate intermediates dominate in DRM reactions. Such evolution of the surface species verifies facile dissociation of both CH4 and CO2 in well-matched rates, promoting coke-resistance DRM reaction over NiMgOx catalyst. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Methane dry reforming Carbon dioxide NiMgOx catalyst Coking Surface intermediates Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Dry reforming of methane (DRM) converts global greenhouse gasses of CO2 and CH4 into the energy-carried syngas of CO and H2 with a proper ratio, which is an effective approach to mitigate with the processes of energy transfer and chemical upgrade (e.g., Fischer-Tropsch synthesis) [1,2]. Intensive catalysis research has proved non-noble metal Ni-based DRM catalysts as the promising one, considering their advantages in terms of comparably high activity, environmentally friendly property, and low-cost economy than noble metal catalysts [3–5]. However, in view of thermodynamically endothermic nature of the atmospheric DRM reaction, the existed experimental observations demonstrate that the sintering of active metal sites and poisoning of deposited coke species still serve as the main issues for causing catalyst deactivation and thus hindering industrial application [6,7]. Unremitting efforts are made to promote structural stability and coke-resistance ability of the Ni-based DRM catalysts [8–11]. In general, the reduced size of Ni nanoparticle promotes the dispersion degree and initial activity as well as anti-coking ability, and nonetheless it leads to unsatisfactory structural stability of metallic Ni sites along with irreversible aggregation problem [12,13]. Engineering the support to well tune the interaction with the Ni site is one of effective strategies for tailoring Ni dispersion, chemical state, and catalytic property. The optimal metal oxides, such as CeO2, ZrO2, La2O3 and γ-Al2O3 have be adopted as the supports to anchor the Ni atoms by affording strong interaction [14–19]. For instance, the CeOx-doped hydroxyapatites can trap the Ni single-atom for preventing the metal sintering and completely suppressing coking processes in the DRM reaction [20]. With aid of a confinement effect by the nanostructured or porous supports, including microporous zeolites, mesoporous silica, layered double hydroxides, etc., the active Ni sites can also be highly dispersed and effectually stabilized [21–27]. The NiO-MgO solid solution-derived catalysts have emerged as a kind of widely researched DRM catalysts with good structural stability of active sites [28–32]. The Ni4 single-site is found to be confined by the MgO(100) surface and the NiMo nanoparticles can also be anchored at the high-energy edge of MgO(111), leading to good anti-metal-sintering stability under the DRM reaction condition [33,34]. On the one hand, MgO and NiO possess face-centered cubic structure with very similar lattice parameters, constructing a solid solution phase with strong interaction. The highly dispersed metallic Ni0 and NiO species can be formed through reductively migration from the solid solution matrix, contributing to a great structural stability of metallic site against sintering. On the other hand, the MgO-related support is particularly rich in Lewis basic sites on the surface for effectively activating adsorbed CO2 and reducing formation of coke species. At high reaction temperature, which is necessary to provide considerable energy for breaking the CH and C = O bonds of CH4 and CO2 with high bonding energies, it is a challenge for ideally matching the reaction rates for activating and converting these two molecules for preventing the formation of coke precursors and deposition of coke species for poisoning the catalyst [35,36]. For instance, the uncontrollable CH4 decomposition into C* species ( C H 4 ( g ) → C ( s ) + 2 H 2 ( g ) , ▵ H 298 K ⊖ = + 74.8 kJ / mol ) has been reported as the main coking process over Ni-Ir/MgAl2O4 catalyst, while the disproportionation of the formed CO (i.e., Boudouard reaction, 2 CO ( g ) → C ( s ) + C O 2 ( g ) , ▵ H 298 K ⊖ = − 172.5 kJ / mol ) has been identified to be responsible for the coke deposition on Ni-La2O3/5A catalyst [37,38]. Therefore, the coking reaction pathway and mechanism as well as the anti-coke stability depend on the choice of the developed catalyst and operating reaction condition [39]. It is still of great enlightening significance to further investigate the coking-relevant key reaction steps over a certain Ni catalyst in terms of capturing the surface intermediate species and exploring the catalytic mechanism. Herein, considering of the acknowledged effects of stabilization on active Ni sites and surface basic property, a classic NiMgOx material with solid solution phase structure has been pre-reduced and adopted as the catalyst in atmospheric DRM reaction. The structure of the working catalyst as well as the coke species deposited during the reactions have been carefully characterized. Furthermore, in this contrastive study, the temperature-programmed catalytic property evaluation and ex- or in-situ spectral inspection experiments have been combined to systematically investigate the DRM reactions integrated with the key steps including adsorption and dissociation of CO2, dissociative decomposition of CH4 and disproportionation of CO at different temperatures. The temperature-dependent formation of the surface adsorbates and intermediates have been identified, providing insights into the key DRM reaction steps over the NiMgOx catalyst with high anti-coke ability. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation NiMgOx catalyst was synthesized via the precipitation method. Typically, 2.28 g Ni(NO3)2, 2.01 g Mg(NO3)2, and 4 g oxalic acid were dissolved in 100 mL deionized water, followed by addition of excess urea. The resulting solution was stirred at 600 rpm and 90 °C for 12 h. After filtering and washing with deionized water until neutral pH, the precipitate was dried at 100 °C. The obtained powder was calcined in 50 mL/min air flow at 500 °C for 4 h with 4 °C/min. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The loading amounts of Ni and Mg in the catalyst were measured using an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES, PerkinElmer Avio 200). The actual loading of Ni and Mg in NiMgOx catalyst was 48.3 and 20.1 wt.%, respectively. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54 Å, Bruker AXS D8 Advance). The operating current was 40 mA and accelerating voltage was 40 kV. For transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) elemental mapping, the images were collected on a FEI Tecnai G2 F20 microscope. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were obtained at −196 °C on Micromeritics ASAP 2460. The specific surface area and pore volume were calculated with Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method, respectively. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Mettler Toledo TGA 2 in 50 mL/min air and 10 °C/min heating rate. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were obtained on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha electron spectrometer with monochromatic 150 W Al Kα radiation, and the binding energy was referenced to the C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV. Raman spectra were collected with 325 nm excitation laser (Horiba HR Evolution). The acquisition time was 10 s with 2 times accumulation. 2.3 Temperature-programmed surface reaction of DRM For temperature-programmed surface reactions (DRM-TPSR), 50 mg NiMgOx catalyst was mixed with 1000 mg quartz sand, loaded in the fixed-bed reactor, and pre-reduced in 30 mL/min H2 at 500 °C for 60 min. After cooling down to 300 °C in 30 mL/min Ar, the atmospheric DRM-TPSR test was proceeded from 300 to 800 °C with 2 °C /min. The online MS (Hiden QGA) signals of CO2 (m/z = 44), CH4 (m/z = 16), CO (m/z = 28) and H2 (m/z = 2) in outlet gasses were recorded. For CO2, the fragments at m/z = 28 and m/z = 16 possess approximately 10% relative intensity in comparison with m/z = 44. In view of the overlapping with MS signals of CO and CH4, the contribution form CO2 fragments has been subtracted proportionally. 2.4 Catalytic DRM reaction The DRM reaction was carried out in a fixed-bed reactor with a quartz tube (inner diameter = 8 mm). 500 mg catalyst (40–60 mesh) and 1000 mg quartz sand were uniformly mixed in the quartz tube. After pre-reducing in 30 mL/min H2 flow at 500 °C for 1 h and purging in Ar for 30 min, the reaction was performed in an atmosphere of CO2: CH4: Ar = 10: 10: 30 mL/min (GHSV = 6000 h-1, 1 atm) from 300 to 800 °C. The outlet gasses were analyzed by an online gas chromatograph (GC 2060, Shanghai Ruimin) equipped with a hydrogen flame ionization detector (FID) and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) connected to a methane reformer. The conversion of CH4 and CO2 and ratio of H2 to CO are determined by the following equations: CH4 conversion (%) = [F in(CH4) - F out(CH4)] / F in(CH4) × 100% CO2 conversion (%) = [F in(CO2) - F out(CO2)] / F in(CO2) × 100% H2/CO ratio = F out(H2) / F out(CO) It could be assumed that the deactivation of the catalyst followed a first-order reaction kinetics, and the deactivation reaction rate constant (k d) was calculated as follows: k d = {ln [(1 – X final) / X final] - ln [(1 – X initial) / X initial]} / t where X initial and X final represent the conversion of CO2 and CH4 at initial and final time point, and t represents the reaction time. The thermodynamic equilibrium conversions of CH4 and CO2 at different temperatures were calculated by Aspen Plus software. CO, H2 and H2O as the potential products of DRM under 1 atm, the RGibbs reactor model, and the Peng-Robinson equation was adopted in the analyses [40]. 2.5 In-situ spectral investigation In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectra were obtained on a Nicolet iS10 spectrometer equipped with a liquid nitrogen cooled MCT detector and an in-situ cell supplied by Harrick. For the CO2 adsorption process, the catalyst and KBr with a mass ratio of 1:1 were ground and mixed evenly, pre-reduced in H2 (30 mL/min) at 500 °C for 1 h, and then purged in Ar (30 mL/min) for 0.5 h. The background spectra were recorded in Ar at steady state and at the indicated temperatures. CO2 and Ar (2 and 28 mL/min) were introduced into the cell to monitor the signal of the adsorbate species during the adsorption process. For the DRM reactions, the catalyst was pre-reduced in H2 at 500 °C and then stabilized at the target temperature (500, 550 or 650 °C) under Ar (30 mL/min). CO2 (1 mL/min), CH4 (1 mL/min) and Ar (28 mL/min) were fed into the cell, and the changes of intermediate species were recorded during the reactions. All background spectra of the pre-treated catalysts were collected at the selected temperature. Each spectrum was obtained with 32 cumulative scans and a resolution of 4 cm-1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic DRM performance of NiMgOx catalyst at different temperatures NiMgOx catalyst was pre-reduced in pure H2 at 500 °C for 1 h and its catalytic performance was evaluated in the atmospheric DRM-TPSR reaction under CO2: CH4: Ar = 10: 10: 30 mL/min. The normalized MS signals of the converted CH4 and CO2 as well as the formed H2 and CO are plotted as a function of reaction temperature, as shown in Fig. 1 A. With increasing temperature, the conversions of both CO2 and CH4 rise, while CO and H2 are correspondingly produced as the products. In either the low temperature range of 300–500 °C or the high range of 650–800 °C, CH4 and CO2 are converted in similar reaction rates, as evidenced by their almost coincided MS signal curves. However, in the moderate reaction temperature range of 500–650 °C, the CH4 conversion displays a higher reaction rate than the CO2 conversion, as presented by the larger slope of the MS signal curve. Meanwhile, H2 also shows a higher production rate in comparison with CO. The DRM-TPSR result reveals the activation and conversion of CH4 and CO2 strongly depend on the reaction temperature, and their degrees of dependency are distinctly different. The steady-state DRM performance of the pre-reduced NiMgOx catalyst was further evaluated from 300 to 800 °C under CO2: CH4: Ar = 10: 10: 30 mL/min for clarifying the temperature-dependent conversion of CH4 and CO2, as shown in Fig. 1B. Three reaction stages are illustrated in the light of the difference between CH4 and CO2 conversions. At the temperature below 500 °C or beyond 650 °C, the CO2 conversions are always slightly higher than the CH4 conversion, whereas in the range of 500–650 °C, higher CH4 conversions are achieved relative to the CO2 conversions. For instance, at 550 °C, the conversion of CH4 and CO2 is 50.1% and 42.3%, respectively. The H2/CO ratio curve in Fig. 1C also reflects such temperature dependence. In the low temperature range (≤500 °C), the H2/CO ratio increases from ca. 0.33 at 300 °C to 0.95 at 500 °C. At 550 and 600 °C, the ratio is 1.40 and 1.26, respectively, which are considerably higher than 1.00 as the stoichiometric ratio. In the high temperature range (≥650 °C), the H2/CO ratios are in a range from 0.95 to 1.05, which is close to the stoichiometric ratio value. Based on the above transient-state TPSR and steady-state reaction results over NiMgOx catalyst, the unsatisfactory performance is observed at low temperatures (≤450 °C) due to the low ability of the catalyst on activating CH4 and CO2 as two chemically stable molecules. However, within the moderate reaction temperature range from 500 to 650 °C, significant variation trends are observed with respect to the ratios of both CH4/CO2 conversion and H2/CO production. As summarized in Fig. 1D, both the ratios are close to 1 at 500 and 650 °C, whereas the ratios are remarkably higher than 1 at 550 °C. Such a striking contrast of catalytic performance at 500–650 °C should be related to the temperature-dependent rate matching degree of the CO2 and CH4 activation, and it also should be determined by the temperature-dependent competition degree between DRM main reaction and the undesired side reactions. Therefore, 500, 550 and 650 °C are selected as the reaction temperature, the temperature-dependent catalytic stability and key reaction steps in the NiMgOx-catalyzed DRM have been investigated in the following sections. The long-term stability of NiMgOx catalyst at these three reaction temperatures was first explored, as shown in Fig. 2 . At 500 °C, the initial conversions of CH4 and CO2 are relatively low, which are ca. 27% and 29%, respectively (Fig. 2A and 2B). After 48 h DRM reaction, the conversions are steadily dropped to 12% and 15% for CH4 and CO2, respectively. Following a first-order deactivation kinetics, the deactivation reaction rate constants were calculated as k d = 2.1 × 10–2 h-1 and k d = 1.6 × 10–2 h-1 for CH4 and CO2, respectively. The H2/CO ratio exhibits a volcano-shape variation trend with the reaction time, which is increased from 0.82 to 1.10 in the initial 9 h and finally decreased to 0.51 at 48 h (Fig. 2C), suggesting unmatched reaction rates between CH4 and CO2 conversion within the DRM reaction at 500 °C. At 550 °C, a rapid deactivation within 9 h is observed. The conversion of CH4 is declined from 49% to 35% (k d = 5.7 × 10–2 h-1), whereas that of CO2 is decreased from 41% to 34% (k d = 2.7 × 10–2 h-1). Correspondingly, the falling H2/CO ratio is also obtained from 1.25 to 0.95, indicating lower conversion of CO2 relative to CH4 at 550 °C. A superior stability is achieved at 650 °C. Within 78 h, the CH4 and CO2 conversions are slowly and synchronously reduced, which are 74–65% and 79–74%, respectively. The initial CH4 conversion at 650 oC shows a slight deviation from the thermodynamic equilibrium, suggesting there may exist side reactions to convert CH4 such as decomposition, which will be discussed inin the following sections. The deactivation rate constant k d values are 5.7 × 10–3 and 4.1 × 10–3 h-1, which are an order of magnitude lower than that observed at 500 and 550 °C. The matched conversions of CO2 and CH4 contribute to the stable H2/CO ratio that can be maintained at 0.90 within the whole reaction. The comprehensive catalytic performance of NiMgOx catalyst can be comparable to that of the literature Ni-Mg-based DRM catalysts, as summarized in Table S1 in Supplementary Material. 3.2 Characterization of spent NiMgOx catalysts after DRM reactions 3.2.1 Structure of spent NiMgOx catalysts The XRD patterns of as-prepared and spent NiMgOx catalyst after the DRM reactions at 500 °C (for 48 h), 550 °C (for 9 h) and 650 °C (for 78 h) are presented in Fig. 3 A. The as-prepared sample exhibits the characteristic peaks of MgNiO2 solid solution phase (PDF#24–0712). Its (111), (200), (220), (311) and (222) planes are located at 37.1°, 43.1°, 62.6°, 75.1° and 79.1°, respectively. The feature of metallic Ni0 phase (PDF#70–1849) is absent. However, for three spent catalysts after DRM reactions, the main peak of MgNiO2(200) is reserved while the rest of the peaks disappear in the XRD patterns. The typical peaks of the (111), (200) and (220) planes of metallic Ni0 phase are emerged at 44.5°, 51.8° and 76.4°, indicating the reduction of Ni from MgNiO2 solid solution matrix during the DRM reactions. That is, the metallic Ni0 and the MgNiO2 solid solution are co-existed in the NiMgOx catalyst under the reaction conditions. With increasing reaction temperature from 500 to 650 °C, the intensity of metallic Ni0-related peaks increases and their peak widths at half height are decreased. Specifically, the crystalline size of Ni in the spent catalyst at 500, 550 and 650 °C is calculated as ca. 6.6, 10.4 and 15.4 nm according to Scherrer formula, which are close to the nanoparticle size of the working NiMo/MgO-based DRM catalyst with 17 nm [34]. It suggests that during the NiMgOx-catalyzed DRM reactions at 500–650 °C, the small-size metallic Ni0 nanoparticles can still highly disperse on surface of MgNiO2 solid solution support without severe metal sintering. For the as-prepared NiMgOx catalyst, the TEM image shows that is consisting of the stacked particles with a few tens of nanometer in size (Fig. S1). Clear lattice fringes with 0.21 and 0.24 nm are related to (200) and (111) planes of MgNiO2 solid solution, respectively (Fig. S2). For the spent NiMgOx catalyst after 650 °C DRM reaction for 78 h, the TEM image illustrates the feature lattice fringes of MgNiO2(111) as well as Ni(111) with d = 0.20 nm (Fig. 3B). The images of EDX element mapping illustrate uniform dispersion of Ni, Mg and O species at nanoscale without self-aggregation of Ni as large particle, as shown in Fig. 3C-F. By combining with the XRD pattern in Fig. 3A, the reduction from MgNiO2 to metallic Ni during the reaction at 650 °C cannot cause the reductive sintering of Ni species. The Ni 2p XPS spectra provide chemical state of Ni species in the spent NiMgOx catalysts after the DRM reactions at different temperatures (Fig. 4 A). By deconvolution fitting analyses, the peaks at 852.3, 855.1 and 861.2 eV in binding energy correspond to Ni0, NiO and satellite, respectively. The oxidative Ni2+ species in MgNiO2 solid solution phase dominate over the metallic Ni0 species for three spent catalysts. The ratio of Ni0/Ni2+ gradually increases with increasing the reaction temperature, which is 10/90, 13/87 and 20/80 for the spent catalyst after the reaction at 500, 550 and 650 °C, respectively, as summarized in Table 1 . These spectra confirm the co-existence of the MgNiO2 solid solution and the metallic Ni0 sites due to the reductive formation within the high-temperature DRM reaction, and these results are in accord with the TEM images and XRD patterns. 3.2.2 Characterization of formed coke species For three spent catalysts, a XRD characteristic peak of C(002) plane at 26.0° (PDF#89–8487) suggests the deposition of coke species (Fig. 3A). Their peak area values are significantly different, suggesting that the coke formation and deposition are strongly related to the reaction temperature. Specifically, although the DRM reaction proceeded for a shortest time-on-stream of 9 h at 550 °C, it causes the greatest amount of deposited coke species. Therefore, the irreversible coke poisoning rather than the Ni metal sintering is responsible for the rapid deactivation of the DRM reaction at 550 °C. In contrast, only a small coke amount is observed on the spent catalyst at 650 °C for 78 h, revealing that the satisfactory long-term stability in terms of steady CH4 and CO2 conversions and H2/CO ratio is attributed to the anti-metal-sintering and anti-coke-poisoning abilities of the catalyst at 650 °C as a proper reaction temperature. Furthermore, Raman spectral characterization was conducted on the spent catalysts to investigate the distribution of the deposited coke species. The main D and G bands of the coke species are observed in Fig. 4B. The D band can be specifically divided into D1, D3, and D4 bands. The D1 band at 1325 cm-1 corresponds to defects and transverse optical phonon modes in the graphene lattice, and the D3 band at 1220 cm-1 represents amorphous carbon, and the D4 band at 1495 cm-1 indicates disordered graphite lattices, while the G band at 1595 cm-1 is attributed to the formation of perfect graphitic crystals with E2g symmetry mode and a high degree of graphitization [41]. The D1 and G bands were fitted with Gaussian function, whereas the D3 and D4 bands with Lorentzian function. The area proportions of these bands are summarized in Table 2 . The D1/G band area ratio gradually decreases with an increase of the reaction temperature, which is 2.20, 1.92 and 1.07 for the spent catalyst after the DRM reaction at 500, 550 and 650 °C, respectively, indicating that a higher reaction temperature can lead to a higher graphitization degree of the coke species [42,43]. The formation of coke species during the DRM reaction proceeds via sequential process, coupling and polycondensation of the CHx* (x = 0–3) species decomposed from CH4 into various coke species with different graphitization degrees [6,7]. The coke formation occurs in a high reaction rate and causes facile transformation of the coke precursors from amorphous form into perfect graphite carbon at a high temperature. Therefore, in a case of the NiMgOx-catalyzed DRM reaction, although a relatively higher temperature of 650 °C leads to a higher graphitization degree of coke in comparison with that at the lower temperatures of 500 and 550 °C, a high DRM reaction rate and a remarkably low deposition amount of coke suggest that under such proper reaction temperature, the catalyst still possesses large number of the free active sites to efficiently catalyze the DRM reaction, exhibiting a superior anti-coke-poisoning stability. 3.3 Key reaction steps of DRM at different temperatures 3.3.1 Thermodynamic analyses The Ni-catalyzed DRM reaction may proceed associated with several key side reactions in a complex reaction network, including CH4 decomposition, CO disproportionation, CO2 methanation and reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reactions [44]. For DRM reaction and several key steps, diagrams of the reaction enthalpy (ΔH) and Gibbs free energy (ΔG) are plotted as a function of temperature (50–700 °C). The ΔH and ΔG diagrams in Fig. 5 highlight the highly endothermic nature of DRM and CH4 decomposition as well as RWGS reaction, whereas CO disproportionation and CO2 methanation reactions are highly exothermic. It indicates that, at high temperatures, DRM, CH4 decomposition and RWGS reactions are thermodynamically favored, whereas CO disproportionation and CO2 methanation reactions are inhibited to a certain extent. Specifically, at high temperatures, these reactions exhibit convergent ΔG values close to zero, indicating that a strong thermodynamical competition exists among these reactions. On one hand, the co-existence of the primary DRM reaction with other reaction steps can apparently influence the product selectivity. For instance, simultaneous occurrence of DRM and RWGS has been reported over a Ni-Co/Al-Mg-O bimetallic catalyst [45]. RWGS reaction allows the excessive CO2 and H2 to be converted into CO and H2O for decreasing the H2/CO ratio of the outlet gasses. However, in a case of the NiMgOx-catalyzed DRM reaction, RWGS reaction could not occur as the primary reaction route at 500–650 °C considering of the ≥1 H2/CO ratios (Fig. 1). On the other hand, CH4 decomposition and CO disproportionation reactions are closely related to formation of coke species on catalyst at high reaction temperatures. The deposited coke species via these two reactions can block the active metal sites on the catalyst or infiltrate the support pores, leading to deactivation of the target DRM reaction. In view of the above issues, the coking-relevant key reaction steps, including the CO2-free CH4 decomposition and CO disproportionation as well as CO2 activated dissociation, have been explored at different reaction temperatures in the following sections. 3.3.2 Temperature-dependent CO2-free CH4 decomposition reaction The steady-state reaction of CO2-free CH4 decomposition (CH4→C + 2H2) was investigated at three selected temperatures by monitoring the formation of H2 as gaseous product with an online MS. As illustrated in Fig. 6 A, the normalized MS signal intensity of H2 production becomes higher within the initial reaction stage (<10 min) as increasing temperature. Specifically, the initial reaction rate of the H2 production at 550 and 650 °C is 2.5 and 4.5 times as high as that at 500 °C (25.7 and 47.0 vs. 10.3, × 10–7 cps), as shown in Fig. 6B. At 500 and 550 °C, the H2 production from CH4 decomposition can occur steadily in relatively low rates within 60 min. However, the reaction temperature as high as 650 °C causes a rapid and complete deactivation, which almost no H2 product can be formed after 20 min. To explore the coke deposition issue that is expected as the primary reason for such severe deactivation, TGA and Raman spectral characterizations were performed on the spent catalysts after 60 min CH4 decomposition reactions at three temperatures. The TGA curves in Fig. 7A-C show that the amount of the oxidized coke species is 68.9%, 83.0% and 39.0% over the catalyst reacted at 500, 550 and 650 °C, respectively, apparently indicating temperature-dependent coke deposition. The CH4 decomposition reaction for H2 production can still steadily occur at 500 and 550 °C even under the higher coke deposition amount level, whereas the reaction can be suppressed at 650 °C with the relatively lower coke deposition amount. This observation rules out the possibility that the deposition amount of coke species serves as the primary and single affecting factor for the deactivation of the CH4 decomposition reaction. The Raman spectra of deposited coke species are revealed in Fig. 7D-F. According to the fitting result, the ratio of D1/G band area is 1.89, 1.67 and 1.17 for the spent catalyst at 500, 550 and 650 °C, respectively, as listed in Table 2. An apparently higher D1/G ratio indicates a higher degree of graphitization for the coke species over the catalyst reacted at 650 °C. Therefore, in comparison with the reactions proceeded at low temperatures of 500 and 550 °C, the reaction at 650 °C allows the CH4 molecules to be more efficiently activated and transformed into coke precursors and perfect-crystallization graphitic coke species for irreversibly blocking the active sites and deactivating the CH4 decomposition reaction. Each D1/G band area ratio value observed in the CH4 decomposition reaction is close to the ratio obtained on the spent catalyst in the DRM reactions at identical temperature, as summarized in Table 2, indicating that the decomposition of CH4 without participation of CO2 might be the main origin of the coke formation during NiMgOx-catalyzed DRM reaction at 500–650 °C. However, at 650 °C, a sharp contrast exists between the great stability of the DRM reaction for 78 h and the deactivation of the CO2-free CH4 decomposition within 20 min. A part of the contributions is the important catalytic role of the synergistically activated CO2-relevant adsorbate species in reacting with the partially dissociated CHx* (x = 1–3) species for suppressing the coupling of completely dissociated C* precursor into coke species [20]. Another part of the contributions is the participation of surface oxygen species that may be derived from either the lattice oxygen of the metal oxides or the dissociative O* species from adsorbed CO2 [32,46,47]. Furthermore, it has been reported that the presence of H2 or CO can reduce the reaction rate of CH4 decomposition and promote migration and removal of the coke species from the active metal surfaces [48]. 3.3.3 Temperature-dependent CO disproportionation reaction CO disproportionation (2CO→CO2+C) also represents one of the side reactions for causing coke deposition in the DRM reaction. The steady-state CO disproportionation reaction was investigated by monitoring the MS signal of CO2 production at different temperatures. As depicted in Fig. 8 A, the initial normalized MS signal intensity of CO2 production decreases with increasing reaction temperature, which is 17.8, 13.3 and 6.9 (× 10–8 cps) for the catalyst reacted at 500, 550 and 650 °C, respectively. Such variation tendency is associated with the exothermic nature of the CO disproportionation reaction. The deactivation degree in the CO2 production within 60 min is related to the reaction temperature. As presented in Fig. 8B, a relatively low reaction temperature of 500 °C leads to a more significant decline from 17.8 to 5.4 (× 10–8 cps) relative to a slight decline from 6.9 to 4.9 (× 10–8 cps) at 650 °C, which might be due to the poisoning effect by different deposited coke species. The TGA curves are presented in Fig. 9A-C, quantifying the coke deposition amount that is 49.2%, 47.1% and 37.5% over the spent catalyst after the CO disproportionation reaction at 500, 550 and 650 °C, respectively. Based on the fitted Raman spectral signals, as shown in Fig. 9D-F, the D1/G area ratio for the coke species is estimated as 1.33, 1.14 and 0.68 for the catalyst reacted at 500, 550 and 650 °C, respectively. Such high coke graphitization degree might be due to the specific environment with lack of hydrogen species during the CO disproportionation reaction [49]. In comparison with the CH4 decomposition reaction, the CO disproportionation reaction at same temperature displays not only the remarkably lower reaction rate (i.e., CO2 production exhibits two order of magnitudes higher MS signal intensity than H2 production) but also the reduced amount of the deposited coke species (TGA result). On the other hand, the CO disproportionation causes much lower D1/G area ratios of the coke species relative to the DRM and CH4 decomposition reactions (e.g., 0.68, 1.07 and 1.17 for CO disproportionation, DRM and CH4 decomposition at 650 °C, respectively). Therefore, by combining the extremely lower reaction rate and the distinctly higher graphitization degree of the coke species, it can be expected that CO disproportionation is not the main coking reaction route in the NiMgOx-catalyzed DRM reaction at 650 °C. 3.3.4 DRIFT spectra of CO2 dissociation at different temperatures Towards CO2 dissociation on the pre-reduced NiMgOx catalyst, the in-situ DRIFT spectra were recorded in a range from 300 to 650 °C, as presented in Fig. 10 . The spectral band assignment has been summarized in Table 3 with respect to the accurate position and vibration mode. The signal located at 3600–3400 cm-1 is related to surface hydroxyls. The bands at 2400–2200 cm-1 are attributed to fed gaseous CO2, while the bands at 2170 and 2110 cm-1 are assigned to formed gaseous CO product. The characteristic bands in the low wavenumber range indicate the presence of bicarbonates, carbonates and formates normally on the surface basic sites of MgO or MgNiO2, including carboxylates (approximately 1750 cm-1), bicarbonates (1640–1725, 1250–1210 cm-1), monodentates (1610–1595, 1340–1330 cm-1), bidentate carbonates (1555–1545, 1290 cm-1), and monodentate carbonates (1475, 1420, 1075, 1030, 860–850 cm-1) [50–56]. As the spectra displayed, at a low temperature of 300 °C, CO2 molecules can be activated and dissociated into carboxylates, bicarbonates, bidentate and monodentate carbonates on the catalyst surfaces. No signal of CO gas is emerged, while the bidentate carbonates exhibit the highest signal intensity relative to other adsorbate species. With increasing temperature, the carboxylate species display unchanged band intensity but slight redshift due to the temperature effect. At above 350 °C, the monodentate formates and monodentate carbonates are steadily formed as the dominant surface species with significantly enhanced intensity. The bands of bicarbonate species also become more intense from 500 °C. Furthermore, the surface hydroxyl species reveal negative peak as increasing temperature, suggesting its consumption by reacting with the adsorbate species for transformation into formates and bicarbonates [11]. The gaseous CO is readily detected at high temperature (≥400 °C), which might be originated from the desorption of metal carbonyl adsorbates and the decomposition of formate species [38]. The absence of characteristic bands of Ni-CO* intermediates in 2100–1850 cm-1 indicates an extremely weak adsorption strength of CO* on Ni surfaces at high temperatures and it also illustrates facile desorption of CO as the final product from the catalyst. To sum up, CO2 molecules can be effectively dissociated on the surface of NiMgOx catalyst at high temperatures, and the distribution of the adsorbates is strongly determined by the temperature. 3.3.5 DRIFT spectra of DRM reactions at different temperatures The DRIFT spectra of the NiMgOx-catalyzed DRM reactions at three temperatures were monitored for identifying the temperature-dependent formation and transformation of key intermediate species. For the DRM reactions at 500, 550 and 650 °C, the features of the gasses including the co-fed CH4 (3014 and 1305 cm-1) and CO2 (2400–2200 cm-1) as well as the formed CO (ca. 2178 and 2111 cm-1) are observed. Considering of their much stronger intensity relative to other surface intermediate species, the spectra are presented in a wavenumber range from 2050 to 800 cm-1, as shown in Fig. 11 . For the DRM reaction at 500 °C, the spectra were recorded in the initial 10 min, as shown in Fig. 11A. A series of intermediates are observed with clear characteristic bands, such as carboxylates (1753 cm-1), bridging carbonates (1680 cm-1), bicarbonate (1657 cm-1), monodentate formate (1599, 1341 and 1331 cm-1), bidentate formate (1579 and 1365 cm-1), bidentate carbonate (1560 and 1545 cm-1) and monodentate carbonate (1482, 142, 1025 and 856 cm-1), as summarized in Table 3. In this wavenumber range, the gaseous CH4 also exhibits a δ(CH) vibration band at 1305 cm-1. When the temperature increases up to 550 °C, as presented in Fig. 11B, the same kinds of surface intermediates are identified, and only minor peak position shifts are observed from the spectra. However, the relative intensity ratios of the bands are different between the DRM reactions at 500 and 550 °C. Relative to the bidentate carbonates that serve as the primary species at 500 °C, the monodentate and bidentate formates become the most intense bands while the bicarbonates and carboxylates show especially enhanced band intensity at 550 °C. Furthermore, the monodentate carbonates also exhibit weaken intensity when the temperature increases from 500 to 550 °C. The DRIFT spectra of the DRM reaction at 650 °C are illustrated in Fig. 11C. Within the initial 10 min, the bidentate formates serve as the dominant intermediates followed by the monodentate formates. The signals of monodentate and bidentate carbonates as well as carboxylates species are relatively low in intensity, while the bands of the bicarbonates are absent in the spectra. At a higher reaction temperature, CH4 molecules can be dissociated into higher amounts of CHx* (x = 1–3) fragments and H* species (CH4→CHx*+H*). In the presence of the active H* species, the formate species can be efficiently produced via either the hydrogen-assisted CO2 dissociation (CO2*+H*→COOH*) or the hydrogen-involved transformation from CO2-derived carbonate adsorbate species [57–59]. Furthermore, a combination of CHx* and H* dissociated from CH4 and O* species originated from CO2 can also produce formates as intermediates. These CO2-relevant steps can be significantly accelerated at a higher temperature, and therefore, a raised reaction temperature leads to a promoted ratio of formates to carbonates with the aid of more CHx* and H* species dissociated from CH4 as well as effectively activated CO2-derived surface species. In the sequence, the facile decomposition of formates occurs for accomplishing the formation of CO and H2 as final products. At 650 °C as a proper reaction temperature, CO2 and CH4 can be synergistically activated and converted in well-matched high reaction rates, which is benefited from the highly effective transformation of the related adsorbates and intermediates. In contrast, at a relatively low temperature of 500 °C, not only the insufficient supply of CHx* and H* species from CH4 dissociation but also the poorly activated CO2-derived surface species cause the unsatisfactory conversions of both CO2 and CH4, evidenced by the catalytic DRM-TPSR results (Fig. 1A). Above spectral information of the DRM reaction intermediates can also be contrasted with the surface species evolution in CH4-free CO2 dissociation process at same temperature. Specifically, at the temperature as high as 650 °C, the bicarbonates and carbonates serve as the primary surface species during the CO2 dissociation, whereas the formates dominate in the DRM reaction, highlighting again that a facile dissociation of CH4 with synergistic CO2 activation is necessary for achieving satisfactory catalytic performance in DRM reaction. Furthermore, there also exists clear spectral evidence for clarifying the role of the supplied H* species in the DRM reaction. As revealed in the spectra recorded in the CH4-free CO2 dissociation process (Fig. 10), the surface hydroxyl species are proposed to participate in the inter-transformation of the surface adsorbates due to its negative signal. However, the nearly steady signal of the hydroxyl species maintains in the DRM reactions at 500–650 °C (Fig. S3). Although the hydroxyl species can be consumed in several reaction steps, e.g., reacting with CO2*, CHx* and CHxO*, it can be replenished by the formation processes, such as O*+H*→OH* and O*+CHx*→C*+OH* [60,61]. 4 Conclusions The NiMgOx catalyst was prepared with MgNiO2 solid solution phase structure and applied in the DRM reaction. The catalyst structure evolution, catalytic performance and reaction pathway are systematically investigated at different reaction temperatures. The structural characterization results demonstrate that the metallic Ni0 sites and the solid solution phase are co-existed in the spent catalyst after the reactions. The catalytic evaluation results reveal 650 °C is a proper reaction temperature for synergistic activation and dissociation of both CH4 and CO2 in high rates, contributing to satisfactory conversions, H2/CO ratio, and anti-coke stability in a 78 h DRM reaction. A relatively low temperature at 550 °C causes severe coke deposition and rapid deactivation within 9 h due to unmatched activation rates between CH4 and CO2. Two main possible coking processes of CH4 decomposition and CO disproportionation were further explored at different temperatures. The endothermic CH4 decomposition without aid of the CO2-relevant adsorbates can proceed in a high initial reaction rate for production of H2 gas at 650 °C but severe poisoning by the deposited coke species, which is identified as the primary coking process. In contrast, the endothermic CO disproportionation exhibits a low reaction rate for CO2 production and a high graphitization degree of coke species at 650 °C, which can be eliminated as the main coking process. The in-situ DRIFT spectra identify the surface species in CO2 dissociation process and DRM reactions over NiMgOx catalyst at different temperatures. The carbonates and bicarbonates serve as the primary adsorbates with co-existence of the carboxylate and formates during the CO2 activated dissociation, whereas the formates become the dominant intermediate species in the DRM reactions. Specifically, at the optimal reaction temperature of 650 °C, the intense bands of the bidentate and monodentate formates verify the facile dissociation of both CH4 and CO2 in well-matched rates, promoting the anti-coke DRM reaction over NiMgOx catalyst. coredata.dc:description: With pre-reduced NiMgOx catalyst, the structure evolution, catalytic performance, surface species and coking-related reaction steps are investigated in methane dry reforming (DRM) at selected temperatures. Satisfactory conversion of CH4 and CO2, H2/CO ratio, and anti-coke stability are achieved in long-term (78 h) reaction at 650 °C as a proper temperature. The characterizations evidence co-existence of metallic Ni0 and solid solution phases in the working catalysts. Combined catalytic evaluation and coke analysis reveal that, at 650 °C, endothermic CO2-free CH4 decomposition shows a high initial rate for H2 production but severe coke deposition for rapid deactivation, serving as the primary coking process. In contrast, exothermic CO disproportionation exhibits a lower reaction rate and a higher coke graphitization degree. The in-situ DRIFT spectra demonstrate that carbonates and bicarbonates serve as the primary adsorbates during CO2 dissociation process, whereas formate intermediates dominate in DRM reactions. Such evolution of the surface species verifies facile dissociation of both CH4 and CO2 in well-matched rates, promoting coke-resistance DRM reaction over NiMgOx catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Investigation into the coking-related key reaction steps in dry reforming of methane over NiMgOx catalyst
